Interesting Stones

A girl named Tomori likes to collect stones. There are so many types of stones in our world, that if we assign each type an integer number, it could be as large asÂ $10^7$.

One day Tomori lined up her stones in a row. A stray cat came and said, â€œYour stones are not interesting.â€ The cat thinks a row of stones is interesting if and only if:

EveryÂ continuous subsequence of the row containsÂ at least oneÂ stone ofÂ uniqueÂ type, i.e. no other stoneÂ in this subsequenceÂ has that same type. (Only need to be unique within the subsequence.) (The entire row is a subsequence of itself.)

(A continuous subsequence of an arrayÂ ğ‘[0â€¦ğ‘›âˆ’1]Â is a subsequenceÂ ğ‘[ğ‘–],ğ‘[ğ‘–+1],â€¦,ğ‘[ğ‘—] whereÂ 0â‰¤ğ‘–â‰¤ğ‘—<ğ‘›.)

Tomori wants to make friends with the cat. Can you develop a program to help her quickly determine whether her rows of stones are interesting?

Input

The first line contains an integerÂ ğ‘‡(1â‰¤ğ‘‡â‰¤200), the number of test cases. ThenÂ ğ‘‡ test cases follow.

The first line of each test case contains an integerÂ ğ‘›Â (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤10000), the number of stones in Tomoriâ€™s row. The second line containsÂ ğ‘›Â non-negative integers (valuesÂ < $10^7$) separated with single spaces, the types of stones in Tomoriâ€™s row.

Output

For each test case, output a single line of the word â€œYesâ€ if the row of stones is interesting, otherwise output â€œNoâ€. Trailing whitespace or line break will be ignored.

Sample Input

Sample Output

Example Explained

This row is insteresting. I marked some subsequences (not all of them) in different colors, and the unique item(s) within them are marked red. You can check that for all subsequences, there is at least one unique item within.

Limits

  • Time limit:Â 2 sÂ for C/C++;Â 4 sÂ for Java/Python
  • (Stack+Heap) Space limit: 512 MB

Hints

  1. Solve the problem inÂ ğ‘‚(ğ‘›logâ¡ğ‘›)Â time with divide and conquer.

  2. You may get â€œTime Limit Exceededâ€ for the last 1 ~ 3 tests (depends on how good your code is). To overcome it,Â you need pre-processing. Why? Because we need aÂ fast enough method to do unique check and unique finding. Make it as fast as possible.Â Itâ€™s crucial!Â And pre-processing, by its name, is something that happens before the recursion even starts.

    Considering that itâ€™s hard to realize its necessity, more details are provided here. See the following figure. IsÂ 3Â unique within the subsequence between the brackets? Yes, because theÂ previous and next positionsÂ where anotherÂ 3Â shows up are both outside the subsequence. This way it only costsÂ ğ‘‚(1)Â time to check uniqueness, as long as we build up these â€œarrowsâ€ before the recursion starts. And your scan-and-find-unique procedure canÂ early stopÂ (see the next hint).

    So you need 2 utility arrays, each of the same length as the row. And to build them up, you may want to temporarily use a hashmap. SeeÂ unordered_map (C++11),Â map (C++),Â HashMap (Java),Â dict (Python).

  3. To handle theÂ worst case,Â it would be better to start from both ends â€¦?Â That would be the key to getting the last 10 points.

    These two optimizations, i.e. pre-processing and handling the worst case, are both fighting a single common enemy:Â unbalanced recursion tree. You all know from class that partitioning at middle +Â Î˜(ğ‘›)Â dividing/combining time =Â Î˜(ğ‘›logâ¡ğ‘›)Â total time. But what if the partitioning could happen everywhere? The recursion tree could be highly unbalanced, and it wouldnâ€™t finish inÂ Î˜(ğ‘›logâ¡ğ‘›)Â even if each node still costÂ Î˜(ğ‘›)Â time. Draw on a paper and check it yourself.

    Thatâ€™s why the unique-finding procedure should be fast and able toÂ early stopÂ once it finds a unique element (no need to do the full scan every time). And thatÂ starting from both endsÂ is a simple yet effective way toÂ short-circuitÂ the worst case where the partitioning always happens at â€¦?

    Hope this problem illustrates the significant impact that the cost of each recursive call can have on the total running time, particularly in the case of an unbalanced recursion tree.

  4. Try brute-force as last resort. Good outcomes.

  5. If you get wrong answer on the 1st test case, it surely means your algorithm is wrong. Yes, a simple check based on some necessary condition can kill most cases (same points as brute-force), but this problem is not that simple.

No more hints after this final update.

Quick facts about recursion in real world

  1. As recursion is typically used in D&C problems, you should notice thatÂ there is such thing as stack space limitÂ in operating systems. Simply put, very deep recursion or very large local variables may causeÂ stack overflow. Even itâ€™s 2024, the OS on your PC probably still has a small default stack limit of 1MB/8MB/â€¦

  2. But as stated on theÂ OJ home page, stack space memory on this platform is counted together with heap space memory into total memory usage, not to be limited separately. You should only get stack overflow (would show as RuntimeError in the last 1 or 3 test cases) if you wrote really bad code. Additionally for Python users, please set a special parameter to allow for deep recursion. SeeÂ Special notes for Python.

    • But donâ€™t blame every RuntimeError on that. Your RuntimeErrors would mostly be caused by index out of range. Check the input value constraints carefully.

  3. In real world applications outside classroom, deep recursion should be avoided by switching to iterative algorithms. If thatâ€™s not possible, you can still get an iterative program by manually simulating the call stack. But thatâ€™s another story.

Special notes for Python

  • IMPORTANT: The recursion depth of this problem may exceed the default recursion limit of Python.Â You should addÂ import sysÂ andÂ sys.setrecursionlimit(10005)Â to the beginning of your code.

  • Please avoid unnecessary list expanding operations. Python is too slow to afford that. For example,

    Python code written in adherence to good programming practices should pass all test cases.

Minimum edge sum

You are given two separate rows of vertices. Letâ€™s label the vertices, always from left to right, asÂ $ğ´_1$ â€¦ $ğ´_ğ‘›$ â€‹Â for the first row andÂ $ğµ_1$ â€¦ $ğµ_ğ‘š$ â€‹Â for the second row. Every vertex is assigned with an integer value,Â $ğ‘_ğ‘–$Â forÂ $ğ´_ğ‘–$Â andÂ $ğ‘_ğ‘—$ â€‹Â forÂ $ğµ_ğ‘—$ â€‹Â (1â‰¤ğ‘–â‰¤ğ‘›Â andÂ 1â‰¤ğ‘—â‰¤ğ‘š, same for the following).

In this problem you are asked to draw edges to construct a bipartite graph from the given two rows of vertices. By using the termÂ bipartite graph, we mean that every edge you draw should connect a vertexÂ $ğ´_ğ‘–$Â in the first row to a vertexÂ $ğµ_ğ‘—$Â in the second row, and we label this edge asÂ ğ¸ğ‘–ğ‘—, whose weight is defined asÂ ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘—=âˆ£$ğ‘_ğ‘–$ âˆ’ $ğ‘_ğ‘—$âˆ£Â (the absolute difference between the two verticesâ€™ values).

While drawing edges, you should follow theseÂ rules:

  1. The graph should be bipartite, as stated above;
  2. There should be an edge connectingÂ $ğ´_1$ â€‹Â andÂ $ğµ_1$ â€‹, i.e.Â ğ¸11â€‹Â exists;
  3. There should be an edge connectingÂ $ğ´_ğ‘›$ â€‹Â andÂ $ğµ_ğ‘š$, i.e.Â ğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘šâ€‹Â exists;
  4. Every vertex should be connected to at least one other vertex (i.e. no â€œisolated verticesâ€);
  5. There can be at most one edgeÂ ğ¸ğ‘–ğ‘—Â between any vertex pairÂ (ğ´ğ‘–,ğµğ‘—)Â (i.e. no â€œmultiple edgesâ€);
  6. Edges should not cross each other. The following image shows examples of a valid and an invalid graph, with the bold red edges crossing each other.

To be more specific, if you draw an edgeÂ ğ¸ğ‘–ğ‘—, then you cannot draw any edgeÂ ğ¸ğ‘ğ‘Â where (ğ‘<ğ‘–Â ANDÂ ğ‘>ğ‘—) OR (ğ‘>ğ‘– ANDÂ ğ‘<ğ‘—), because the two edges will cross each other.

TheÂ edge sumÂ of a graph is defined as the sum of all edgesâ€™ weights. Your goal is to find a bipartite graph with theÂ minimum edge sum, while following the rules above.

Input

The first line of the input contains two integersÂ ğ‘›Â andÂ ğ‘š, separated with a single space, the number of vertices in the first and second row, respectively.

The second line containsÂ ğ‘›Â integersÂ $ğ‘_1$ â€¦ $ğ‘_ğ‘›$ â€‹, separated with single spaces, the values of the vertices in the first row.

The third line containsÂ ğ‘šÂ integersÂ $ğ‘_1$ â€¦ $ğ‘_ğ‘š$ â€‹, separated with single spaces, the values of the vertices in the second row.

Output

An integer, the minimum edge sum of a valid bipartite graph. Trailing whitespace or line break will be ignored.

  • 1â‰¤ğ‘›,ğ‘šâ‰¤1000
  • Specially for test cases 1~6:Â 1â‰¤ğ‘›,ğ‘šâ‰¤10
  • AllÂ $ğ‘_ğ‘–$, $ğ‘_ğ‘—$Â are within the value range of a 16-bit signed integer, i.e.Â âˆ’32768â‰¤$ğ‘_ğ‘–$, $ğ‘_ğ‘—$â‰¤32767

In macOS Catalina, Apple introduced the read-only system volume, which is a dedicated, isolated volume for system content. Now, macOS Big Sur adds strong cryptographic protections to store system content on a signed system volume (SSV).
